articles.headline: Blagojevich, Guilty on 1 of 24 Counts, Faces Retrial
articles.snippet: The judge declared a mistrial on 23 charges, the bulk of the case, after the jury said it was hopelessly deadlocked. Prosecutors promised a new trial.
articles.abstract: The judge declared a mistrial on 23 charges, the bulk of the case, after the jury said it was hopelessly deadlocked. Prosecutors promised a new trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Prosecutors here once said that the conduct of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, was so despicable it would make Abraham Lincoln “roll over in his grave,” but 12 jurors in the federal corruption case against him were apparently not all so certain.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Susan Saulny

articles.headline: In Mott’s Strike, More Than Pay at Stake
articles.snippet: A fight at an apple juice plant pits a company earning record profits against workers determined to resist cuts.
articles.abstract: A fight at an apple juice plant pits a company earning record profits against workers determined to resist cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSON, N.Y.  After nearly 90 days of picketing in the broiling sun outside the sprawling Mott’s apple juice plant here in upstate New York, Michelle Muoio recognizes that the lengthy strike is about far more than whether the 305 hourly workers at the plant get a fatter or slimmer paycheck.

articles.headline: Iraqi Leaders Fear for Future After Their Past Missteps
articles.snippet: Iraq remains haunted by the decisions of the earliest days of the occupation, when the U.S. helped install opposition exiles to lead the country.
articles.abstract: Iraq remains haunted by the decisions of the earliest days of the occupation, when the U.S. helped install opposition exiles to lead the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s political elite, empowered by the American invasion and entrusted with the country’s future, has begun to deliver a damning critique of itself, a grim harbinger for a country rife with fears of more crises, conflicts and even coups as the American military withdraws.

articles.headline: China Sets Strict Rules on Off-Book Loans
articles.snippet: Authorities are worried that banks and trusts are forming partnerships and creating products to evade rules aimed at slowing bank lending and reducing excess credit.
articles.abstract: Authorities are worried that banks and trusts are forming partnerships and creating products to evade rules aimed at slowing bank lending and reducing excess credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Disappointed with his low savings deposit rate, a 29-year-old chemical company salesman named Zhang Zhenlei says he took $19,000 out of his savings account last November and bought into a higher-yielding investment trust through his bank’s wealth management division.

articles.headline: A Dutch City Seeks to End Drug Tourism
articles.snippet: Struggling to reduce traffic and crime, Maastricht is pushing to make its legalized use of recreational drugs a Dutch-only policy.
articles.abstract: Struggling to reduce traffic and crime, Maastricht is pushing to make its legalized use of recreational drugs a Dutch-only policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands  On a recent summer night, Marc Josemans’s Easy Going Coffee Shop was packed. The lines to buy marijuana and hashish stretched to the reception area where customers waited behind glass barriers.

articles.headline: Lilly Stops Alzheimer’s Drug Trials
articles.snippet: The company said patients who had taken a drug intended to reduce plaque in the brain showed worse functioning than those who had taken a placebo.
articles.abstract: The company said patients who had taken a drug intended to reduce plaque in the brain showed worse functioning than those who had taken a placebo.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eli Lilly halted two late-stage clinical trials of an experimental Alzheimer’s treatment on Tuesday, representing a setback to one leading theory on treating the degenerative disease and a new blow to Lilly’s business prospects.

articles.headline: Given Money, Schools Wait on Rehiring Teachers
articles.snippet: Some of the nation’s biggest school districts are balking at using federal aid to hire teachers right away, citing looming budget deficits.
articles.abstract: Some of the nation’s biggest school districts are balking at using federal aid to hire teachers right away, citing looming budget deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: As schools handed out pink slips to teachers this spring, states made a beeline to Washington to plead for money for their ravaged education budgets. But now that the federal government has come through with $10 billion, some of the nation’s biggest school districts are balking at using their share of the money to hire teachers right away.

articles.headline: Tea Party Choice Scrambles in Taking On Reid in Nevada
articles.snippet: Senator Harry Reid seems to have found a lifeline in his Republican opponent, Sharron Angle, who has stumbled in her campaign.
articles.abstract: Senator Harry Reid seems to have found a lifeline in his Republican opponent, Sharron Angle, who has stumbled in her campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev.  Sharron Angle leaned across a table in her campaign office here, defending her suddenly embattled campaign to defeat Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader, under the gaze of a half-dozen advisers and an official videographer packed into the room.
